title: 115_hr1188
content:
The "Adam Walsh Reauthorization Act of 2017" authorizes $20,000,000 for the SOMA program annually from 2018 to 2022. Additionally, not less than $60,000,000 is allocated to the United States Marshals Service for enforcing registration requirements from 2018 to 2022. SEC. 4 amends the duration of sex offender registration requirements for certain juveniles from 25 years to 15 years. SEC. 5 allows public access to juvenile sex offender information, including offenders adjudicated delinquent. SEC. 6 protects local governments from state noncompliance penalties under SORNA. Section 125 of the Adam Walsh Act is amended to change references from "jurisdiction" to "State", update subsection (a) references, and add a provision for calculating funding allocation to local government units. The Adam Walsh Act amends Section 125 to allocate funding to local government units based on a formula determined by the State. SEC. 7. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION TO BE INCLUDED IN ANNUAL REPORT ON ENFORCEMENT OF REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 is amended to include additional information in the annual report on enforcement of registration requirements. This includes the number of sex offenders registered in the National Sex Offender Registry, categorizing them as adults or juveniles. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 is amended to include information on the number of sex offenders registered in the National Sex Offender Registry, categorized as adults, juveniles, or adults required to register due to juvenile conduct. It also includes data on the percentage of juvenile offenders adjudicated delinquent and prosecuted as adults. SEC. 8. Amends supervision requirements for released sexually dangerous persons. Probation and Pretrial Services Officers' duties expanded to include individuals under section 4248. 

SEC. 9. Extends civil remedy for survivors of child sexual exploitation and human trafficking to 10 years. 

SEC. 10. Establishes Tribal Access Program. SEC. 10. The Attorney General can provide technical assistance and equipment to tribal governments to access Federal criminal information databases. Tribes can reimburse the Department of Justice Working Capital Fund for this assistance. SEC. 11. Alternative mechanisms for in-person verification. SEC. 11. ALTERNATIVE MECHANISMS FOR IN-PERSON VERIFICATION. Amends the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act to allow sex offenders to comply with verification requirements through an alternative method approved by the Attorney General, with at least one in-person appearance per year. The alternative method must be approved by the Attorney General to ensure public safety. SEC. 12. CLARIFICATION OF AGGRAVATED SEXUAL ABUSE. Amends the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act to clarify aggravated sexual abuse. SEC. 13. COMPREHENSIVE EXAMINATION OF SEX OFFENDER ISSUES. SEC. 13. COMPREHENSIVE EXAMINATION OF SEX OFFENDER ISSUES. The National Institute of Justice will submit a report to Congress on the impact of long-term registration of juvenile sex offenders within a year of the Adam Walsh Reauthorization Act of 2017.
